column13: Improve lib bz2 dependency installation
column20: build.sh will die on more recent versions of Ubuntu when we attempt to install lib32bz2-1.0. This package now comes in a multi-arch flavor, so what we want is libbz2-1.0:i386. This patch simply attempts to use the old name first and then the new one if needed.

column13: Fix patch opening toFront behavior
column20: Currently, opening a patch from the MainFrame's menu properly brings it to the front. Opening a patch from an existing open PatchFrame results in the new patch appearing behind the patch that the open was invoked from. This is happening indirectly as a result of the hardcoded reference to MainFrame in FileMenu which gets reused in PatchFrame. We simply grab a reference to the parent frame and use it when creating the open dialog and we get the correct toFront behavior. The open dialog is also then positioned relative to the invoking frame.
column21: Currently, opening a patch from the MainFrame's menu properly brings it to the front. Opening a patch from an existing open PatchFrame results in the new patch appearing behind the patch that the open was invoked from. This is happening indirectly as a result of the hardcoded reference to MainFrame in FileMenu which gets reused in PatchFrame. We simply grab a reference to the parent frame and use it when creating the open dialog and we get the correct toFront behavior. The open dialog is also then positioned relative to the invoking frame.

column13: GUI: zoom and pan
column20:
Hi @JohannesTaelman,
Here is my implementation of zooming and panning for the patcher. The new UI interactions are as follows:

Mouse wheel events control zoom in and out for a PatchFrame; zoom occurs relative to the mouse pointer
Zoom can also be controlled via View menu items and their associated keyboard shortcuts
Holding the middle mouse button and dragging initiates a pan

Everything else should function roughly as usual. The zoom shouldn't have any effect on the structure of the patch itself. In some cases, there was a bit of complexity involved in achieving this. I've done a bit of testing, but I'm sure there are probably some lingering issues. I'm going to continue testing as we review the changes. I thought it would be good to get it in front of you now.
Known Issues

Graph/plot objects are not being repainted properly under zoom in live mode, working on fix
Need to update copyright notice for new files

Feel free to contact me here or over on the forums, and we can discuss the implementation details. I'm @urklang over there.
Best,
Nicolas

column13: GUI: theme system and editor
column20:
Moves color definitions into a Theme type. Adds a ThemeEditor UI that allows the user to pick colors and save and load themes (accessible under the Window menu). A saved theme becomes sticky in user preferences; the current theme saved in preferences is load at startup. Reverting to the default theme is supported in the editor UI as well.
Additionally, a custom color can be set per Dial, and this is persisted along with the patch. If a custom color is set, it overrides the background color coming from the theme.

column13: GUI: fix undo for promotion and replace
column20:
Both object replace and edit were resulting in multiple undo steps as well. This patch makes sure that they're squashed down as well as in the original promotion case:

undoing a promotion connection removes the connection and returns the object to its unpromoted state
undoing a replace does the expected thing
object editing is kept out of the patch edit history, previously this would cause useless undo states to accumulate. I think what we probably want eventually is undo and redo for the object editor itself.

This also fixes an issue with the keyboard shortcuts that was caused by the menu enabled state not being updated.
column21:
Both object replace and edit were resulting in multiple undo steps as well. This patch makes sure that they're squashed down as well as in the original promotion case:

undoing a promotion connection removes the connection and returns the object to its unpromoted state
undoing a replace does the expected thing
object editing is kept out of the patch edit history, previously this would cause useless undo states to accumulate. I think what we probably want eventually is undo and redo for the object editor itself.

This also fixes an issue with the keyboard shortcuts that was caused by the menu enabled state not being updated.

Also, selection and manipulation for both comments and hyperlinks was a bit unresponsive. The strut on the left part of the comment created an event dead zone. This patch makes these interactions a bit more forgiving.

column13: GUI: persist bounds and active tab of object editor
column20:
This pull request causes the object editor to persist its bounds and active tab. This came up as an annoyance on the forums.
There is a bit of trickiness involved for the patcher object case because these data have to be stored on the instance rather than the object type due to the fact that the patcher recreates an AxoObject (the type) whenever updateObj occurs. There is a small change that makes "Revert" behave similarly.

There is a small change that makes "Revert" behave similarly.

column13: GUI: patch rendering performance improvements
column20:
This PR improves the responsiveness of the patch ui by:

avoiding unnecessary repaints
trying to only paint regions of the canvas that actually need to be repainted
changing the net rendering code such that nets are drawn relative to their own bounds rather than to the size of the patch (this was resulting in many unnecessary net repaint calls because all nets overlapped even when drawing on nonoverlapping regions)

column13: GUI: fix param highlight repaint
GUI: add visible cable type selector to PatchFrame
GUI: preserve default mousewheel behavior without modifier
GUI: clean up alt modifier panning
column20:
With Mark's latest commit, we've moved to a single modifier, ALT, to control zooming and panning. It is used in two ways: either to 1. allow zooming from mouse wheel events (from the trackpad or from a real mouse wheel) or 2. to allow smooth panning with a single finger drag or mouse motion. Without ALT, the trackpad has the default mouse wheel behavior.
This patch fixes two things:

We ensure that the drag cursor is only shown once a drag has actually started, not just when ALT is pressed.
Previously the ALT behavior wasn't handled correctly when a UI component implementing KeyListener was focused (DialComponent for example). We now route this event to the correct handler in the main JLayeredPane, so ALT panning works as expected everywhere in the canvas.
column21:
With Mark's latest commit, we've moved to a single modifier, ALT, to control zooming and panning. It is used in two ways: either to 1. allow zooming from mouse wheel events (from the trackpad or from a real mouse wheel) or 2. to allow smooth panning with a single finger drag or mouse motion. Without ALT, the trackpad has the default mouse wheel behavior.
This patch fixes two things:

We ensure that the drag cursor is only shown once a drag has actually started, not just when ALT is pressed.
Previously the ALT behavior wasn't handled correctly when a UI component implementing KeyListener was focused (DialComponent for example). We now route this event to the correct handler in the main JLayeredPane, so ALT panning works as expected everywhere in the canvas.

column13: GUI: fix zoom and repaint strategy
column20:
The fundamental problem with our current zooming approach is that the components themselves are unaware of the fact that they're in a layer context that might apply a scale factor. So a call to repaint() from inside a component results in the unscaled region being repainted, not the entire zoomed region in the containing layer.
This patch uses a custom RepaintManager in such a way that standard repaints end up setting the appropriate zoomed region as dirty and swing takes care of the rest. Painting is completely removed from ZoomUI aside from the one place where we perform the scaling of a layer. We also return to our repaint strategy from before zoom was originally merged where each component is responsible for calling repaint in the appropriate place.
column21:
The fundamental problem with our current zooming approach is that the components themselves are unaware of the fact that they're in a layer context that might apply a scale factor. So a call to repaint() from inside a component results in the unscaled region being repainted, not the entire zoomed region in the containing layer.
This patch uses a custom RepaintManager in such a way that standard repaints end up setting the appropriate zoomed region as dirty and swing takes care of the rest. Painting is completely removed from ZoomUI aside from the one place where we perform the scaling of a layer. We also return to our repaint strategy from before zoom was originally merged where each component is responsible for calling repaint in the appropriate place.

column13: GUI: View Separation v1
column20:
Warning: this is a very large patch. The main high-level ideas are as follows:

Eliminate the IS-A relationship between PatchGUI and Patch; create a clean separation between PatchModel and PatchView. A PatchView redraws itselfs when the PatchModel has changed.
Ideally, the PatchModel should be ignorant of all details of how it might be displayed or processed.
Try to ensure that everything that is touched by SimpleXML persistence doesn't call or depend on Swing.
Create corresponding View classes for various parts of the model, objects, attributes, parameters, displays, etc. Move everything rendering related out of the pure model classes. This will make it easier to develop alternative renderers. Model updates flow back from GUI event handling code into the model, so technically our Views are more like ViewControllers. There is not explicitly a separate controller class for each of these submodels.
In general, practicality over purity. I've tried to achieve the practical result of view separation and am not necessarily rigidly following a pattern or using any framework. There is still room for improvement.

I've done quite a bit testing with the tutorial and demos patches. Things seem pretty stable so far, but there are bound to be corner cases in such a large patch. Undo/redo is still using serialization. A model-based version of undo will come later.

column20:
Noticed this bug in master when developing something on one of my feature branches.
Current behavior:

Select "Clear all presets" from the preset assign menu without first "Including in current preset" -> NPE
or
Include and then exclude a parameter, then clear all. -> NPE

It's annoying to check for and then reassign null when dealing with fields that may be persisted. It would be nice to come up with a better strategy for default values for these fields. Going to give that some thought, but for now here's the easy fix.

column13: Piccolo2D Renderer and View Separation v2
column20:
This patch builds on my previous View Separation patch. It includes everything from that with various improvements, so my previous notes apply.
In addition, I've implemented an alternative renderer based on the Piccolo2D scene graph framework. This gives us a fully zoomable UI among many other benefits including performance and code simplification. In many cases, Piccolo handles things that we previously had to implement manually. The Swing renderer still exists and may be switched on via a compile time preference (see line 489 of Preferences.java). The View Separation refactoring makes it convenient to have multiple renderers living side by side.
Another significant addition is the use of the Merlin java2d renderer. This improves java2d performance in general, specifically with anti-aliasing. It has made it into the official Java 9 repository, but must be manually included and enabled for use in earlier java versions.
For the new renderer, as a start, I've tried to stick to a design that mostly mirrors what the Swing renderer does unless it became very inconvenient technically. There are a couple of minor tweaks to the visual style that I think work better than the existing design across multiple zoom levels. Another potentially contentious change is for mouse wheel event behavior: by default it controls zoom rather than pan, but this is switchable via a preference value. For me personally, this is way more commonly used than the existing trackpad pan behavior, but I'm open to switching the default the other way if needed. In that case, mouse wheel zoom is hidden behind the Ctrl/CMD modifier as in the previous zoom patch. Pressing the middle mouse button pans as in the previous patch too.

column13: FW:load mutable instrument elements data dynamically
Keyed-in unit interpretation
column20:
Hi,
These patches allow modifiers to be used when typing values into dials, e.g. 'x' for ratios, 'h' for frequencies, 's' for periods, 'd' for decibels, '/' for bpms. 'k'ilo and 'm'illi prefixes are supported, and extraneous spaces and letters should be silently eaten. I've tried to make it as "do what I mean" as I could without making it contradictory, ambiguous, or unpredictable.
I'm sure there'll be room for improvement, but I thought I'd get this out there.
Lisa

I've tried to make it as "do what I mean" as I could without making it contradictory, ambiguous, or unpredictable.
I'm sure there'll be room for improvement, but I thought I'd get this out there.
Lisa

column21:
Thanks for these changes.
I discussed this with @JohannesTaelman , the conclusion was:
we definitely want to use flow execution order in the future (thank you for implementing)
however, we need to supply a logical migration path for users, and supporting two execution orders is likely to confuse...
so the current idea is we would activate this on a 'major update release', so that users are 'ready' for more major changes... this would become the new model.
to help with migration etc.
a) a method will be added to allow users to override execution order on patches
b) old patches migrated to use (a) so that their existing behaviour does not change.
thats current idea... if you have others would be cool to hear.
we will also need to look at the impact on things object references (e.g. tables) and also send/receive.
so for now, Ive updated the new experimental branch  (our new dev branch) with your changes to support the new EO, but Ive not taken the patch settings/ui code, as this will be subject to change due to the above.
(your changes are in PatchModel.java, I applied them manually, as the code has since be refactored to support MVC)
Thanks
Mark

column13: Fix single selected object deletion
column20: Currently, if you click on one object to select it (rather than drawing a selection bounding box), it grabs focus and then subsequent key operation events like deletion and arrow key movement have no effect because they don't reach the handler attached to Layers. If we keep the focus on Layers, then a selected-by-click object acts exactly like bounding box select objects.
column21: Currently, if you click on one object to select it (rather than drawing a selection bounding box), it grabs focus and then subsequent key operation events like deletion and arrow key movement have no effect because they don't reach the handler attached to Layers. If we keep the focus on Layers, then a selected-by-click object acts exactly like bounding box select objects.

column13: Re-enable object editor
column20: Currently, in experimental, selecting "edit object definition" from the object menu does nothing. The editor frame is created, but remains invisible. This PR re-enables it and simplifies persistence of its bounds and active-tab state. The editor itself will need further verification as we continue development on this branch.

This PR re-enables it and simplifies persistence of its bounds and active-tab state. The editor itself will need further verification as we continue development on this branch.

column13: Fix tricky textfield recursive edit bug
column20: The document associated with a textfield is modified recursively and an exception is thrown if edited when there are multiple views of it open. setModelUndoableProperty triggers a model event that ultimately causes a string to be compared to the current textfield text which has already changed by the time the comparison occurs. Calling setModelUndoableProperty inside an invokeLater defers this comparison and all copies of the textfield track the edit as we expect.
column21: The document associated with a textfield is modified recursively and an exception is thrown if edited when there are multiple views of it open. setModelUndoableProperty triggers a model event that ultimately causes a string to be compared to the current textfield text which has already changed by the time the comparison occurs. Calling setModelUndoableProperty inside an invokeLater defers this comparison and all copies of the textfield track the edit as we expect.

column13: Fix 'new view' live state
column20: If a new view is created of a patch view that is already live, we explicitly unlock it, so the patch is still live, but all views of it are unlocked. This change makes the new view respect the lock state of the patch when it is created (ShowConnect is called during PatchFrame creation if the connection is connected). It doesn't seem like there is a case where ShowConnect will be called, and we would want to explicitly unlock a locked patch.
column21: If a new view is created of a patch view that is already live, we explicitly unlock it, so the patch is still live, but all views of it are unlocked. This change makes the new view respect the lock state of the patch when it is created (ShowConnect is called during PatchFrame creation if the connection is connected). It doesn't seem like there is a case where ShowConnect will be called, and we would want to explicitly unlock a locked patch.

column13: Restore Piccolo
column20:
This patch brings the piccolo renderer back online in a way that is consistent with the current MVC style. By default, patches still open in Swing mode, but the "new view" item in the PatchFrame file menu has been replaced by two new items: "New Swing View" and "New Piccolo View." This makes it possible to have views of both types open simultaneously to compare behavior. The most basic distinction between the two is that Piccolo is scalable: mouse wheel triggers zoom by default, mouse wheel click + drag pans the canvas.
I've also upgraded the Marlin 2D renderer to a more recent release. These changes have made it into Java 9, so this won't be necessary if we end up moving to it later on.
In general the changes are isolated in the piccolo package, but there are a couple of places where I did some minor cleanup outside of it. I've added a way to track the "connected" state of a jack that follows the mvc style so it can be rendered properly; this was broken in experimental previously.
column21:
This patch brings the piccolo renderer back online in a way that is consistent with the current MVC style. By default, patches still open in Swing mode, but the "new view" item in the PatchFrame file menu has been replaced by two new items: "New Swing View" and "New Piccolo View." This makes it possible to have views of both types open simultaneously to compare behavior. The most basic distinction between the two is that Piccolo is scalable: mouse wheel triggers zoom by default, mouse wheel click + drag pans the canvas.
I've also upgraded the Marlin 2D renderer to a more recent release. These changes have made it into Java 9, so this won't be necessary if we end up moving to it later on.
In general the changes are isolated in the piccolo package, but there are a couple of places where I did some minor cleanup outside of it. I've added a way to track the "connected" state of a jack that follows the mvc style so it can be rendered properly; this was broken in experimental previously.

column13: Fix initial undo/dirty state
column20:
There are a couple of undo bugs in 'experimental' right now:

A patch is considered dirty immediately after launch, so the user is prompted to save on close even if no edits have occurred.
By repeatedly undoing after making some edits, it is possible to go beyond the initial state the patch had when it was opened. Visually this looks like everything is removed from the patch view.

This is happening because UndoableEdits accumulate in the UndoManager when a patch is opened; setModelUndoableProperty is called repeatedly during the initialization process. One simple way to fix this is to discard these edits just before a PatchFrame is created. The dirty state works as we expect with this change: 1. A patch is clean immediately after being opened. 2. Undoing all the edits back to the initial state of the patch results in a clean patch and it's not possible to go beyond that initial state.
column21:
There are a couple of undo bugs in 'experimental' right now:

A patch is considered dirty immediately after launch, so the user is prompted to save on close even if no edits have occurred.
By repeatedly undoing after making some edits, it is possible to go beyond the initial state the patch had when it was opened. Visually this looks like everything is removed from the patch view.

This is happening because UndoableEdits accumulate in the UndoManager when a patch is opened; setModelUndoableProperty is called repeatedly during the initialization process. One simple way to fix this is to discard these edits just before a PatchFrame is created. The dirty state works as we expect with this change: 1. A patch is clean immediately after being opened. 2. Undoing all the edits back to the initial state of the patch results in a clean patch and it's not possible to go beyond that initial state.

column13: Avoid raw string concatenation in favor of StringBuilder where possible
column20:
See http://www.pellegrino.link/2015/08/22/string-concatenation-with-java-8.html for background info.
It's possible that the compiler is optimizing some of these cases properly behind the scenes, but by being explicit, we can ensure that we're not making excessive copies of strings. This is particularly important in the code generator where we do a ton of string concatenation.

column13: GUI: fix log (use document length instead of offset)
column20: Background: Previously threw with JDK10, now works as expected.
column21:
Not clear what happened with the Linux build. It just timed out I think. I don't have write access to the main repo so I can't manually restart. The build will restart if you close and open the pull request though.
What is the exception that is thrown here in JDK10? Looking at the docs for 10, the original methods are still there. It seems like getLength() should be equivalent exactly like you have here though. I think the distinction is that if you hold a reference to the Position object that getEndPosition() returns, it will track the end position over time as edits are made and maybe this is useful if you have other Position objects around. But we were just discarding that reference immediately, getting the length should be the same thing.
I'm a little bit surprised that this is the only spot that fails under JDK10. As far as I know, there hasn't been a significant effort to target versions more recent than 8; that's sort of the current canonical API level for the project. But the build process ultimately uses whichever system java it finds; it doesn't enforce using a particular API level. I don't think that there are significant technical reasons why we can't target more recent versions. It's just going to take a bit of testing to find issues. We should be better about documenting exactly which versions are supported and how to build for them.

column13: GUI: fix log (use document length instead of offset)
column20: Background: Previously threw with JDK10, now works as expected.
column21:
Thanks for the feedback - first of all, I don't wanna push anyone moving to a later JDK. I didn't notice any other issues so far, so I thought I will stick to JDK10. Downgrading would be a small thing for me.
Re issue at hand: getEndPosition().getOffset() initially returns 1, not 0. So trying to insert with this offset into the document threw an BadLocationException. Not sure why this behavior is different between the JDKs (tried googling a couple of days ago, but didn't find any concrete hints).

column13: GUI: fix log (use document length instead of offset)
column20: Background: Previously threw with JDK10, now works as expected.
column21: Closed and reopened to restart build.

column13: GUI: fix log (use document length instead of offset)
column20: Background: Previously threw with JDK10, now works as expected.
column21: Wow, the 1, 0 behavior is pretty confusing. I was worried there would be some kind of off by one thing happening there. I'm going to do a little bit more digging to figure out why that might be happening.

column13: GUI: fix log (use document length instead of offset)
column20: Background: Previously threw with JDK10, now works as expected.
column21:
What I've found so far: getEndPosition().getOffset() seems to always be length + 1. In Java 8 inserting beyond the end just inserts at the end. So when we try to to insert at index 1 but the doc length is 0 it doesn't throw an exception. Java 9 and higher will throw.
A zero length document has a start position of 0 and an end position of 1. And then inserting at the end position doesn't work. Confusing. Relevant part of the documentation: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/javax/swing/text/Position.html#getOffset()
Inserting at getLength is what we want here going forward. Also, this is the only place where we call getEndPosition, so this commit should be sufficient.

column13: GUI: fix log (use document length instead of offset)
column20: Background: Previously threw with JDK10, now works as expected.
column21:
Thanks!
I'm hesitant to upgrade to JDK 9 or 10 as they will have a very short lifetimes, and seem to drop support for older systems (32bit...). Yet it is good to prepare for the future...

column13: Fix linux build on experimental branch

column13: Fix travis builds / ensure oraclejdk8
column20:
Closes #443
Travis was using openjdk 11 for linux and java 10 for osx, ignoring whatever was custom installed by the script. The docs suggest using the jdk keyword, but:

oraclejdk8 is no longer preinstalled in the default linux distribution (xenial). travis-ci/travis-ci#10290 recommends using "trusty" or moving to openjdk.
Something similar was happening on osx for xcode8.2 (which is not even shown in the docs).
